project.name: NetDoctor
project.summary: Cross-platform (Windows/Linux/macOS) desktop application for sysadmins to run system and network diagnostics with a polished PySide6 GUI, background workers, exportable reports, and optional advanced features (SNMP, ARP, nmap integration).
project.purpose: Provide a single, polished tool that bundles common diagnostics (ping, traceroute, port-scan, DNS/whois, system overview) into an aesthetic, user-friendly desktop app suitable for production troubleshooting and for showcasing on GitHub.

goals: Provide common network checks (ping, traceroute, port scan, DNS lookup) in a single UI for quick triage
Provide system diagnostics (CPU, memory, disk, network interfaces) to surface resource issues
Run scans in background without freezing the UI
Export results as CSV/PDF and create a shareable diagnostics bundle
Offer advanced tools (SNMP poll, ARP scan, MAC vendor lookup, service checks) as optional features
Ship a polished aesthetic UI suitable for portfolio/demo
user_stories: As a sysadmin I want to run a ping sweep and view results in a sortable table and chart
As a sysadmin I want to run a port scan with concurrency settings and view banners
As a sysadmin I want to view system metrics and sparklines for quick health checks
As a sysadmin I want to save session history and export reports
As a user I want clear warnings about legal and permission implications for network scanning

mvp_features.description: Minimum Viable Product features to build first (focused, high-impact)

features.name: Ping & Ping Sweep
features.details: ICMP ping using raw sockets where permitted, with subprocess fallback to system ping when raw sockets require elevated privileges. Single-host and sweep modes. Results table, latency chart, export to CSV.

features.name: TCP Port Scanner
features.details: TCP connect scanning across ranges with configurable concurrency and timeout. Results table with port/service/banner. Optional nmap integration if system has nmap installed.

features.name: DNS Lookup and WHOIS
features.details: Use dnspython for record lookups (A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, NS, TXT). WHOIS via python-whois or subprocess. Display results in table and raw text pane.

features.name: System Overview
features.details: psutil-driven CPU, memory, disk, network interface metrics and sparklines. Interface table with IP/MAC/default gateway and RX/TX counters.

features.name: Asynchronous Task Runner
features.details: QRunnable + QThreadPool worker model with progress, error, finished signals. UI must remain responsive and allow cancellation.

features.name: Export Results
features.details: CSV export for all result tables. JSON export for session bundles. PDF (optional, post-MVP).

advanced_features_post_mvp.name: ARP Local Network Discovery
advanced_features_post_mvp.details: Optional scapy-based ARP scanning or OS-specific ARP queries, MAC vendor lookup, results table with vendor info.

advanced_features_post_mvp.name: SNMP Poller
advanced_features_post_mvp.details: Use pysnmp to poll common OIDs (if community string provided). Display results in table and allow presets for common OIDs.

advanced_features_post_mvp.name: Nmap Integration
advanced_features_post_mvp.details: If nmap is installed detect it and optionally use it for advanced scans. Provide UI wrapper and parse nmap XML output.

advanced_features_post_mvp.name: PDF Report Generator
advanced_features_post_mvp.details: Generate printable diagnostic reports with ReportLab (or alternative) that include summary cards, charts and raw logs.

advanced_features_post_mvp.name: Network Diagram Generator
advanced_features_post_mvp.details: Generate network diagrams from discovery results using Graphviz or SVG and embed in UI.

advanced_features_post_mvp.name: Live Interface Monitoring
advanced_features_post_mvp.details: pyqtgraph streaming charts for interface bandwidth and latency. Configurable refresh rates.

design_constraints_and_non_functional_re.cross_platform: Windows, Linux, macOS (be careful with raw sockets/ICMP privileges and libpcap dependencies)
design_constraints_and_non_functional_re.no_root_fallback: Implement non-root fallbacks: use subprocess ping and TCP connect for scanning if raw sockets need admin
design_constraints_and_non_functional_re.responsive_ui: All IO/long tasks off main thread; use QRunnable/QThreadPool or qasync for async integration
design_constraints_and_non_functional_re.minimal_external_deps_by_default: Optional extras for scapy, pysnmp, nmap; core works with pure-Python libs and psutil
security_and_privacy: No telemetry by default; logs stored locally only
Explicit user confirmation before performing network scans
Legal/responsible use warning in README and onboarding
design_constraints_and_non_functional_re.packaging: Provide single-file executables via PyInstaller (per-platform builds) or briefcase for native installers
design_constraints_and_non_functional_re.license: Recommend MIT for open-source recruitment visibility

gui_framework.rationale: LGPL-friendly licensing, modern Qt6 features, good community resources. Use Qt Designer for UI files.

core_libraries.requests: HTTP requests if needed for remote lookups (OUI, APIs)
core_libraries.scapy: ARP discovery/advanced packet tasks (optional, depends on libpcap)

layers: core: pure-backend logic modules for each feature (ping, traceroute, portscan, dns, whois, systeminfo, report)
workers: QRunnable/QThread implementations that wrap core functions and emit Qt signals
gui: PySide6 views, widgets, main window, resource management
storage: small SQLite or JSON store for history and settings
cli_fallback: minimal CLI wrapper for headless use and integration tests
tests: pytest tests for business logic and small integration tests
project_architecture_and_components.worker_layer: netdoctor.workers.task_worker -> QRunnable with WorkerSignals (progress, finished, error), uses cancellation flags
project_architecture_and_components.persistence_layer: netdoctor.storage.history (SQLite or JSON), netdoctor.config (JSON for settings)

theme_and_visual_direction.style: Modern admin dashboard, dark-first with light option, subtle accents and micro-animations
micro_interactions: animated success checkmark on completed runs

main_content_area.structure: dynamic view loader, header + content split

Ping.worker: QRunnable ping worker with progress signal

qss_examples.nav: QPushButton#navButton { border: none; padding: 10px; text-align: left; } QPushButton#navButton:hover { background: rgba(255,255,255,0.03); } QPushButton#navButton:checked { background: rgba(20,184,166,0.12); color: #14B8A6; }
qss_examples.card: QWidget.card { border-radius: 10px; background: rgba(255,255,255,0.02); padding: 12px; margin: 8px; }

concurrency_and_worker_model.cancellation: Workers accept a thread-safe cancellation flag that is checked periodically and stops workers gracefully when set.
concurrency_and_worker_model.ui_integration: Connect worker signals to slots that update QTableModels, pyqtgraph plots, and progress bars. Enable/disable action buttons based on state.

fallback_strategies_and_platform_conside.raw_icmp_permissions: Attempt raw socket ping; if permission denied, fallback to calling system ping via subprocess and parse output.
fallback_strategies_and_platform_conside.packet_crafting: scapy optional and depends on libpcap/WinPcap/Npcap; make scapy features optional and auto-detect availability at runtime.
fallback_strategies_and_platform_conside.nmap_integration: Detect nmap binary path and version. If present, present UI option to use nmap and parse its XML output. If not present, keep using built-in TCP connect scan.
fallback_strategies_and_platform_conside.snmp: Require user-provided community strings or credentials. Document security implications.

security_privacy_and_legal.permission_warnings: All aggressive scan actions require an explicit affirmation checkbox 'I have permission to scan this network' that the user must click before running.
security_privacy_and_legal.logging_policy: Logs stored locally only. Provide export functionality only upon explicit user action.
security_privacy_and_legal.data_sanitization: Provide options to redact IPs or usernames in exported reports.
security_privacy_and_legal.legal_disclaimer: Include a prominent notice in the README and in-app settings about responsible use and legal limitations.

testing_strategy.unit_tests: Test pure logic modules, parsers, and configuration handling using pytest.
testing_strategy.integration_tests: Optional, can run on loopback or specialized test network with appropriate markers.
testing_strategy.ui_tests: Manual. Optional automated UI tests using pytest-qt for certain flows.
testing_strategy.mocking: Mock network IO in unit tests where possible (e.g., socket/network calls).

workflows.name: build
workflows.notes: Use platform-specific runners to create PyInstaller builds; Windows runner for Windows executables, Linux runner for Linux builds, macOS runner for Mac builds.

release_process: Create GitHub release with binaries attached
Provide detailed install instructions and changelog
Sign executables if producing official releases

documentation_and_github_polish.docs: Detailed module docs under /docs and developer guide (how to add new scans, how to add a new view)

phase_0_preparation: Create GitHub repository with LICENSE (MIT) and README template
Initialize pyproject.toml with poetry or set up venv + requirements.txt
phase_1_research_and_prototyping: Prototype ping module with raw ICMP + subprocess fallback
Prototype threading model: minimal PySide6 app using QRunnable and signals
phase_2_mvp_backend_and_minimal_gui: Implement backend modules for ping, traceroute (subprocess fallback), DNS, simple TCP port scanner
Implement worker classes and QThreadPool usage
Build minimal GUI skeleton with left nav and a Ping view that runs and shows results
phase_3_polish_mvp: Improve UI/UX, add icons and theme toggle, add settings page
Add unit tests and basic CI
phase_4_advanced_features: Add ARP discovery (scapy optional), SNMP poller (pysnmp), optional nmap integration
phase_5_packaging_and_release: Create PyInstaller builds for each target OS
Publish GitHub release with executables and documentation
phase_6_outreach: Add polished README, demo GIF, blog post 'How I built NetDoctor', share on GitHub/LinkedIn

navigation.left_nav: collapsible rail controlling which view is loaded into the main content area
navigation.lazy_loading: heavy components (pyqtgraph, scapy) are imported/initialized on demand

accessibility_and_responsiveness.keyboard: Ensure tab order, keyboard shortcuts (Ctrl+R run, Ctrl+E export, Ctrl+T theme toggle)
accessibility_and_responsiveness.high_dpi: Use SVG icons and Qt high-DPI scaling (QApplication.setAttribute(Qt.AA_EnableHighDpiScaling))
accessibility_and_responsiveness.contrast: Colors chosen to ensure readable contrast; provide light mode alternative
accessibility_and_responsiveness.tooltips: Provide descriptive tooltips for all controls

options_for_next_output: Produce JSON schematic (this document) for other AI/automation tools (e.g., Cursor)
Produce starter code skeleton with PySide6 app shell + left nav + Ping module using QRunnable and pyqtgraph placeholder
Produce a visual mock (PNG/SVG) of the wireframe and theme
Produce pyproject.toml and requirements.txt with pinned minimal versions
deliverables_and_next_steps.immediate_recommendation: Begin with PySide6 and build Ping + System Overview + Port Scanner module as MVP. I can generate starter skeleton code for these modules next.

setup_commands: pip install -r requirements.txt # or use poetry install
run_dev: or run from VS Code with configured launch.json

notes: Make optional heavy/developer-only dependencies optional extras to keep core install light.
Document admin/root requirements for raw sockets and packet capture.
Be conservative in default scan aggressiveness; default to slow/safe settings.
When integrating external libraries (scapy/pysnmp), add runtime detection and clear UI guidance for missing dependencies.
caveats: Network scanning may be illegal without permission—provide explicit warnings and rate-limit defaults.
Cross-platform packaging (especially macOS signing/packaging) can be more complex than Linux/Windows.
